title: Benjamin DesJardins
text: Benjamin DesJardins majors in Mathematics at SUNY Geneseo, with a focus on actuarial science. In his free time, Ben enjoys cooking, playing The Sims, and walking his two dogs.

title: Benjamin DesJardins
text:
Education
State University of New York at Geneseo | Geneseo, NY  B.A. in Mathematics | Jan 2023 - Dec 2024 
Jefferson Commnunity College | Watertown, NY  A.S. in Mathematics | Sep 2020 - Dec 2022

title: Benjamin DesJardins
text:
Experience
Watertown Savings Bank | Bank Teller | May 2023 - Present 
American Eagle Outfitters | Sales Associate | Jul 2021 - Present 
American Eagle Outfitters | Assistant Merchandise Team Leader | Apr 2022 - Jan 2023 
Jefferson Community College | Peer Tutor | Oct 2022 - Dec 2022

title: NYC Restaurant Inspection
text:
Analyze the DOHMH_NYC_Restaurant_Inspection.csv data.


library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.4.3     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0
âœ” purrr     1.0.2     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)
restaurant <- 
  read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/DOHMH_NYC_Restaurant_Inspection.csv')

Rows: 17633 Columns: 12
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (10): DBA, BORO, STREET, CUISINE DESCRIPTION, INSPECTION DATE, ACTION, V...
dbl  (2): CAMIS, SCORE

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


#Q1a) What are the mean, standard deviation, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum of SCORE for each GRADE of restaurants?

scorePerGrade <- restaurant %>% 
  group_by(restaurant$GRADE) %>%
  summarize(
    score_mean = mean(SCORE),
    score_sd = sd(SCORE),
    score_min = min(SCORE),
    score_q1 = quantile(SCORE, probs = .25),
    score_median = median(SCORE),
    score_q1 = quantile(SCORE, probs = .75),
    score_max = max(SCORE) )

#Q1b) How many restaurants with a GRADE of A are there in NYC? How much percentage of restaurants in NYC are a GRADE of C?

numObs <- restaurant %>% 
  group_by(GRADE) %>% 
  summarize( number = n())

16305 with a grade of A

294 / sum(numObs$number) * 100 

[1] 1.667328


Percentage with grade C
#Q1c)
Provide both (1) ggplot code and (2) a simple comment to describe how the distribution of SCORE varies by GRADE and CRITICAL FLAG.

ggplot( data = restaurant) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = SCORE, fill = restaurant$`CRITICAL FLAG`), bins = 50) +
  facet_grid(. ~ GRADE)




Critical makes up the majority of each grade, and those with the grade A has the highest and most varied scores, those with grade C have much larger scores
#Q1d) Provide both (1) ggplot code and (2) a simple comment to describe how the proportion of CRITICAL FLAG varies by GRADE and BORO.

ggplot(data = restaurant) + 
  geom_bar(aes(x = GRADE, fill = BORO)) +
  facet_wrap(. ~ `CRITICAL FLAG`)




Staten Island and Bronx make up the smallest proportions of boroughs.
Manhattan makes up the largest proportion of each grade. Critical and Not Critical have very similar distributions.
#Q1e) For the 10 most common CUISINE DESCRIPTION values, find the CUISINE DESCRIPTION value that has the highest proportion of GRADE A.

cuiseDescrip <-  restaurant %>% 
  group_by(`CUISINE DESCRIPTION`) %>%
  summarise(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-count) %>% 
  mutate()

head(cuiseDescrip, 10)

# A tibble: 10 Ã— 2
   `CUISINE DESCRIPTION`    count
   <chr>                    <int>
 1 American                  3678
 2 Coffee/Tea                1414
 3 Chinese                   1372
 4 Pizza                     1050
 5 Italian                    689
 6 Bakery Products/Desserts   615
 7 Japanese                   584
 8 Mexican                    582
 9 Latin American             544
10 Donuts                     505


#Q1f) Find the 3 most common names of restaurants (DBA) in each BORO. If the third most common DBA values are multiple, please include all the DBA values.

q2f <- restaurant %>% 
  select(DBA, BORO) %>% 
  group_by(BORO, DBA) %>% 
  summarize(n = n()) %>% 
  mutate(ranking = dense_rank(-n)) %>% 
  filter(ranking <= 3) %>% 
  arrange(BORO, ranking)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'BORO'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

q2f_ <- restaurant %>% 
  group_by(DBA) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  arrange(-n)

#Q1g) For all the DBA values that appear in the result of Q1f, find the DBA value that is most likely to commit critical violation.

q2g <- restaurant %>% 
  filter(DBA %in% q2f$DBA) %>% 
  group_by(DBA, `CRITICAL FLAG`) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  group_by(DBA) %>% 
  mutate(lag_n = lag(n),
         tot = sum(n),
         prop_crit = lag_n / tot) %>% 
  select(DBA, prop_crit) %>% 
  filter(!is.na(prop_crit)) %>% 
  arrange(-prop_crit)

title: Spotify Data
text:
Analyze the spotify_all.csv data.


library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.2     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.4.3     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.2     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0
âœ” purrr     1.0.2     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)
spotify_all <- 
  read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/spotify_all.csv')

Rows: 198005 Columns: 7
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): playlist_name, artist_name, track_name, album_name
dbl (3): pid, pos, duration_ms

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



Q1a
Find the top 10 most popular songs

Q1a <- spotify_all %>% 
  count(artist_name, track_name) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  head(10)



Q1b
Find the five most popular artist in terms of the number of occurrences in the data.frame, spotify_all What is the most popular song for each of the five most popular artist?

Q1b <- spotify_all %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  mutate(n_popular_artist = n()) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate( artist_ranking = dense_rank( desc(n_popular_artist) ) ) %>% 
  filter( artist_ranking <= 5) %>% 
  group_by(artist_name, track_name) %>% 
  mutate(n_popular_track = n()) %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  mutate(track_ranking = dense_rank( desc(n_popular_track) ) ) %>% 
  filter( track_ranking <= 2) %>%   # I just wanted to see the top two tracks for each artist
  select(artist_name, artist_ranking, n_popular_artist, track_name, track_ranking, n_popular_track) %>% 
  distinct() %>% 
  arrange(artist_ranking, track_ranking)



Q1C
Provide both (1) ggplot codes and (2) a couple of sentences to describe the relationship between pos and the ten most popular artists.

Q1c <- spotify_all %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  mutate(n_popular_artist = n()) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate( artist_ranking = dense_rank( desc(n_popular_artist) ) ) %>% 
  filter( artist_ranking <= 10) 
  
# boxplot
ggplot(Q1c,
       aes(x = pos, y = fct_reorder(artist_name, -artist_ranking)) ) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(
    fun = mean,
    color = 'red'
  )

Warning: Removed 10 rows containing missing values (`geom_segment()`).






# histogram
ggplot(Q1c) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = pos), binwidth = 1) + 
  facet_grid(fct_reorder(artist_name, artist_ranking) ~ .  , switch = "y") +
  theme(strip.text.y.left = element_text(angle = 0))

title: DANL Project
section: 2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
text:
2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
The following boxplot shows how the distribution of highway MPG (hwy) varies by a type of cars (class) ğŸš™ ğŸšš ğŸš.

ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy, fill = class),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = "Class", y = "Highway\nMPG")

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
oj <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/dominick_oj.csv')
nvars <- format(round(ncol(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",") 
nobs <- format(round(nrow(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",")
The number of variables is 4; the number of observations is 28,947.
Roses are red
violets are blue.

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.1 Data Summary

Summary statistics (Use skimr::skim())

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.2 Data Visualization

oj %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = log(sales), 
             y = log(price),
             color = brand)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .1) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, se = F) +
  facet_wrap(.~ad) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(legend.position = 'top')

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.3 Data Transformation

ob_sum1 <- oj %>% 
  group_by(brand, ad) %>% 
  summarise(sales_tot = sum(sales, na.rm = T),
            price_mean = round(mean(price, na.rm = T), 2))
